body: Remember you can override time grain functions in `superset_config.py` (see examples) without having to edit source and rebuild!

Issue-Label Bot is automatically applying the label `#bug` to this issue, with a confidence of 0.88. Please mark this comment with :thumbsup: or :thumbsdown: to give our bot feedback! 

 Links: [app homepage](https://github.com/marketplace/issue-label-bot), [dashboard](https://mlbot.net/data/apache/incubator-superset) and [code](https://github.com/hamelsmu/MLapp) for this bot.

Same thing happens to us. 
Clicking on the datasource, `Edit datasource`, changing SQL in the advanced settings doesn't bring new metrics on the visualisation. 
On columns, `Sync columns from source` is not available.

If I click on `view query` I get something like this:

```
SELECT month AS month,
                old_metric AS old_metric
FROM
  (SELECT DATE_TRUNC('month', date_time) AS month,
          COUNT(DISTINCT column_1) AS old_metric,
          COUNT(DISTINCT column_2) AS new_metric
   FROM table
   GROUP BY 1) AS expr_qry
WHERE month >= '1919-06-13 00:00:00'
LIMIT 1000;
```

So the query is not updated with the new column in my modified SQL query.

This sounds neat, as I tend to get confused by all the different conversion functions. I will take a closer look over the weekend. Btw, not that it matters for testing, but there's a conflict that needs rebasing.

@etr2460 Thanks for the tag. I find the monospace easier to read and it sounds like a big win for performance. My biggest concern is how "spaced" out the letters are now. In design we call this tracking or more recently letter-spacing. Check out this bit about [legibility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letter-spacing#Legibility).

1. I think you should try to reduce the amount of spacing.
2. Run it past SQL Lab users. You would be surprised how sensitive people can be about this kind of typographic change. 

Keep me posted!

I apologize Erik, I made a mistake. [Monospace](https://practicaltypography.com/monospaced-fonts.html) of course is a fixed width.

I wonder if it's worth the extra space because of the advantage of spacing out compressed syntax per the link I shared in this comment.

@elibrumbaugh spacing out JSON is definitely a perk for using a monospace font here. I'll try to find some folks who use sql lab on a daily basis for feedback!
Personally I prefer the old style, but I've learned to trust designers in cases like this. If @elibrumbaugh says it's better I'm happy to go with it. :)

@etr2460 tab logic is a little confusing here.
- TABS component: contain a list of TAB component. it can be top level, or row level (display tabs like a row of content in the middle of page)
- TAB component: render single tab. it has 2 mode: render tab itself or render tab content. 
for tab inside the root level TABS, tab's children's visibility depends on if current tab is selected.
for row level tab,   tab's children's visibility depends on if current tab is selected, *and* if tab self is visible (this is my fix).
- regular component (that doesn't hide some of its children components): these components visibility is always depends on its parent's visibility.

This is a very strange error because this works fine on my Mac.  It was only when I tried this on an Ubuntu machine that it caused problems.  The issue is that the `int64` is a `numpy` data type. 
@JohnOmernik, any ideas?
Thanks Beto üôèWe'll def confirm with users first!

Try setting your date time range on your chart to be one day ahead. 

Example: 14-June-2019 to 15-June-2019 will only display data within June 14th. It will not include any data in June 15th.

If you set your date range to be 14-June-2019 to 1 day from now you will see 15-June-2019 data in realtime assuming you are auto-refreshing every 5 minutes.

Side note outside the scope of this PR: I thought before that it could be good to limit/collapse wide columns to say 100 chars by default and allow users to expand it. Maybe a right caret in the column header that widens the column to its full extend?

For `json` specifically, when detected we could also allow a modal on click that would auto-json-format.
Inspect the generated SQL on the explore view and make sure it looks as expected
Would approve solutions suggested in my comment here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/issues/7669#issuecomment-499756804
@kristw may have an answer

It seems like what you are interested into are dropdown menus, not tabs. They're different ui elements. They could be implemented as another dashboard primitive, but it seems like tabs serve most use cases.

`Error: Failed to find Flask application or factory in module "app". Use "FLASK_APP=app:name to specify one.`

@mashciku if you want charts to default to showing all datapoints today instead of yesterday 23:59, set 
`DEFAULT_RELATIVE_END_TIME = 'now'` in `superset_config.py`: https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/0d122431b287b1a34f006d91717d1b4e09136869/superset/config.py#L607-L615
@villebro   Maybe, you need "can queries on Superset" permission, as the API '/superset/queries/xxx' will be called when the query is running long time.

Yes, I know it seems over the board this kind of abstraction, but ideally `@log_this` should go out of the `Log` Model class, since we are making it generic, so in the future `AbstractEventLogger` is a good place for the decorator.

Sorry wouldn‚Äôt a simpler solution be:

```
conn.scalar(select([1]))
return json_success(‚Äò‚ÄúOK‚Äù‚Äô)
```

i.e., we really don‚Äôt care what the JSON response is but rather that the status code is `200`. The try/except handles the failed connection case.

The only way to do this at the moment is by using views as a datasource (where the view is making the join). We understand that there's performance impacts and in general we recommend denormalizing/materializing.

We may add support for joins in the future, where you could define many-to-one relationship to dimension tables (in the datasource editor) and define the join criteria there. Then the columns coming from these tables would show up under the "columns" tab. Presumably the SQL-generation logic would only join as needed.

@etr2460 I'm not really sure what purpose these filters serve (especially for the case were a validator is present) and when values which evaluate to `False` should be `None`. Additionally it seems, 

```
decimal = StringField(
     _('Decimal Character'),
     description=_('Character to interpret as decimal point.'),
     validators=[Optional()],
     widget=BS3TextFieldWidget(),
     filters=[lambda x: x or '.'],
)
```

is somewhat magical as it uses `.` by default (without indicating this to the user) could be defined as, 

```
decimal = StringField(
     _('Decimal Character'),
     description=_('Character to interpret as decimal point.'),
     default='.',
     validators=[Length(min=1, max=1)],
     widget=BS3TextFieldWidget(),
)
```
